column1: A [1] [1] of a connected graph G is a set of vertices whose removal renders G disconnected.

In the mathematical field of graph theory, a [1] [1] (or [2]) is a graph whose vertices can be divided into two disjoint and independent sets U and V, that is every edge connects a vertex in U to one in V. Equivalently, a [1] [1] is a graph that does not contain any [3]-length cycles.
column5:
Vertex sets U and V are usually called the parts of the graph.
The two sets U and V may be thought of as a coloring of the graph with two colors: if one colors all nodes in U blue, and all nodes in V green, each edge has endpoints of differing colors, as is required in the graph coloring problem.
